title: Is it true that only reflected light is visible? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, a life lived without reflection may not be aware of much. Aside from that - look at the sunrise. Not with a mirror now. Squint for a minute, work with me. If you see the sun, that’s light that came from the sun to your eye in more or less straight line. No reflections. If the gist of your question was whether objects are only visible to us due to reflected or scattered light, that is a bit closer to ‘yes’. You can still see an object that’s on fire, or glowing red hot, so things that are emitting visible photons can also be seen (like the sun). For things not innately glowing, the act of your eye seeing them will mean that some light source is hitting the object with enough photons, which subsequently scatter / reflect into your eyes, that your brain constructs ‘seeing’ that object in a way that’ll probably be consistent in how it ‘looks’ as you move around it, make shadows on it, and the like. Part of the opposite side of the coin there is that non-visible light can also reflect and scatter (and ‘glow’ directly from some objects. That facet is not visible to us without help from night vision goggles, or radar dishes, or other artificial aids to detecting photons our human eyes don’t pick up on. (You may be able to take your pet Mantis Shrimp along as a detector for some such light. They have over a dozen light receptors in their eyes, compared to the three for humans, and can see significantly into the IR and UV, relative to us)

I suspect that you really meant to ask “Is it true that we can see an object only when it reflects light to our eyes?” No, that is not true. Light can pass through a transparent or translucent object and we can see the object that way.
